questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
questions.explanation:
Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema. Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure 
(ICP). "Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicate 
a disc swollen from other causes. All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass. Features of papilledema: • Raised ICP • Edema of the optic nerve head • Blockage of axoplasmic flow • Axonal swelling • Collection of extracellular fluid • Painless progressive loss of vision • Enlargement of the blind spot • Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 3: A resident notes the following fundus picture in a patient referred to the ophthalmology OPD 
with visual complaints. What does it suggest? 510 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of 
papilledema. Ophthalmoscopic features of papilledema: • Early-stage: 520 
Sold by @itachibot • Obscuration of the disc margins (nasal margins first) • Absence of spontaneous venous pulsation at the disc • Mild hyperemia of the disc • The blurring of the peripapillary nerve fiber layer • Established papilledema: • The disc appears to be enlarged and elevated (mushroom or dome-shaped) • Macular fan appears • Paton’s lines- circumferential greyish white folds may develop due to the separation of nerve 
fibers • Visual fields show enlargement of the blind spot • Veins become tortuous and engorged • Multiple cotton-wool spots and superficial hemorrhages • Chronic or long-standing (vintage) papilledema: • The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork • Small drusen-like crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface • Atrophic stage: • Secondary optic atrophy
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following conditions show ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral 
papilledema?
questions.explanation:
Ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral papilledema are seen in Foster–Kennedy syndrome. Weber syndrome (superior alternating hemiplegia) is a form of stroke characterized by the 
presence of an ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia. Millard–Gubler syndrome is a lesion of the pons. It is also called ventral pontine syndrome. Benedikt syndrome, also known as paramedian midbrain syndrome, involves the fasciculus of 
oculomotor nerve as it passes through the red nucleus and is characterized by ipsilateral third 
nerve palsy and contralateral extrapyramidal signs such as hemitremor.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 5: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular 
movements. On examination, the eye is white and there are no obvious signs on 
ophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic 
changes is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis. There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common 
causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and 
neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease). 521 
Sold by @itachibot Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss. Ocular movements 
are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations 
known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be 
impaired. On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted 
due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal 
scotoma. The image below shows papillitis. Type

questions.question:
Question 6: A 33-year-old patient has come to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints that her vision 
becomes temporarily blurry after a hot bath in the evening. This resolves by itself after a few 
hours. She has a past history of an episode of painful unilateral optic neuritis, 3 months back 
which resolved with steroids. What is being described here?
questions.explanation:
Episodic, transient obscuration of vision on exertion or on exposure to heat, which recovers on 
resting or moving away from the heat in an isolated optic neuritis patient is called Uhthoff 
phenomenon. It is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis (MS). Option A: Pulfrich’s phenomenon is an illusion of depth perception. It is seen in MS. Option C: Lhermitte’s sign refers to passive neck flexion causing an electric shock-like sensation 
radiating to the spine and shoulders. This is a result of the increased sensitivity of the myelin to 
stretch or traction; it is also seen in MS. Option D: Riddoch phenomenon refers to ability to perceive kinetic but not static targets. It is 
seen in cortical blindness.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question: Question 7: In a patient with multiple sclerosis, which of the following visual field defects is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Central scotoma is more likely to occur with multiple sclerosis. It is also seen with retrobulbar 
neuritis and macular pathology. Option A: Optic chiasma compression causes bitemporal hemianopia Option C: Enlarged blind spot occurs with papilloedema Option D: Tunnel vision occurs in glaucoma, retinitis pigmentosa and Retinal pan 
photocoagulation
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question: Question 8: Optic neuritis is a common presentation in which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation:
523 
Sold by @itachibot One of the common presentations of MS is optic neuritis. Multiple sclerosis (MS) results from 
demyelinating plaques in the central nervous system. Option A: Myasthenia gravis is the autoimmune destruction of the acetylcholine receptors at the 
neuromuscular junction. Option B: Guillain–Barré syndrome is the postinfectious autoimmune-induced destruction of 
peripheral nerves, resulting in an ascending paralysis. Option D: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a disease of the motor nerve fibers of the lateral 
columns and anterior horns of the spinal cord that results in progressive muscular atrophy.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 9: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other 
eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with 
steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette of a patient presenting with decreased visual acuity and a history of 
transverse myelitis which is treated with steroids is indicative of Neuromyelitis optica (NMO). Neuromyelitis optica also known as Devic's disease is an autoimmune demyelinating disease in 
which antibodies are formed against Aquaporin 4 present in the cell membranes of Astrocytes. It 
is characterized by the findings of unilateral or bilateral optic neuritis developing within a few 
weeks of transverse myelitis(demyelination of the spinal cord). The disease may be monophasic or 
recurrent. Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD): Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD associated with AQP4-IgG • At least 1 core clinical characteristic • A positive test for AQP4-IgG using the best available detection method (cell-based assay) • Exclusion of alternative diagnoses Core Clinical Characteristics: • Optic neuritis is usually bilateral and causes severe visual loss. • Acute myelitis- may be severe, transverse and typically longitudinally extensive involving three 
or more contiguous vertebral segments. • Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting • Acute brainstem syndrome • Symptomatic narcolepsy associated with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions For acute cases of NMO, high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange is used. Mycophenolate 
mofetil, rituximab, and glucocorticoids with azathioprine are used for prophylaxis against 
relapses. The FDA has approved satralizumab, a humanized IgG2 monoclonal antibody, for the treatment 
of NMO spectrum disorder with AQP4 antibody positivity. Eculizumab, a complement inhibitor, and inebilizumab, a B-cell depletion agent, are two more 
new drugs that have recently been approved for use in NMO attack prevention. 524 
Sold by @itachibot A history of transverse myelitis with optic neuritis(decreased visual acuity) rules out Multiple 
sclerosis(option D). It is an autoimmune inflammatory and demyelinating disease of the CNS that 
affects both upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN) with involvement of 
sensory system, ocular system and bowel and bladder function. Ocular manifestations of MS 
include Optic neuritis(usually retrobulbar)- decreased visual acuity, internuclear ophthalmoplegia 
and nystagmus.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 10: A middle-aged man with suspected optic neuropathy is being evaluated for visual field 
defects. Goldman perimetry reveals bilateral centrocecal scotomas. Which of the following is 
most likely to be the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Centrocecal scotoma is most commonly seen in tobacco-induced amblyopia. It is also seen in 
vitamin B12 deficiency. Tobacco amblyopia is caused by excessive smoking and chewing of tobacco. The toxic agent 
involved is cyanide found in tobacco. It is characterized by bilateral and gradually progressive 
impairment of central vision. The classic visual field defect is a centrocecal scotoma, often 
involving both the blind spot and the macula. Option B: Ethanol amblyopia is similar to tobacco amblyopia but often presents with peripheral 
neuritis and a "central scotoma". Option C: Methanol amblyopia often results in complete blindness. Option D: Quinine amblyopia results in near-complete blindness with associated deafness and 
tinnitus.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 11: An anxious, young man came to the ER with complaints of having sudden trouble seeing with 
his left eye and a recent history of tripping over things. There was no associated pain or 
difficulty moving the eyes. An ophthalmology consultation was requested. On perimetry, the 
following visual field defect was picked up. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The perimetry result depicts altitudinal hemianopia, which is most commonly seen in anterior 
ischemic optic neuropathy (AION). Altitudinal hemianopia can also be seen in suprasellar tumors and occipital lobe lesions, but the 
frequency is very low compared to that of AION. Hence, AION is the single best answer. The two types of AION are as follows: • Arteritic AION- caused by giant-cell arteritis • Non-arteritic AION (NAAION)- more common Clinical features: Note: Corticosteroids are not proven to be effective in NAAION. Question 12: What does the given fundoscopic picture suggest? 513 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given fundoscopic image clearly depicts cupping, thinning of the neuroretinal rim, and nasal 
shifting of vessels. This are characteristic of glaucomatous optic atrophy.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following conditions is not associated with optic atrophy?
questions.explanation:
Leprosy is not associated with optic atrophy. All the other given conditions can cause optic atrophy. Causes of optic atrophy: • Primary optic atrophy • Optic neuritis • Compression by tumors and aneurysms 526 
Sold by @itachibot • Hereditary optic neuropathies • Toxic and nutritional optic neuropathies • Trauma • Secondary optic atrophy • Chronic papilledema • Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy • Papillitis • Consecutive optic atrophy • Extensive retinal photocoagulation • Retinitis pigmentosa • Prior central retinal artery occlusion • Glaucomatous optic atrophy
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 14: A 24-year-old man with a history of pernicious anemia was referred to ophthalmology for 
complaints of gradually progressing visual disturbances. On perimetry, which of the following 
defects is most likely to be seen in him?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of pernicious anemia with gradually progressive visual disturbances is 
suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. B12 deficiency is known to cause centrocecal scotoma and it is an important cause of nutritional 
optic atrophy.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 15: A 15-year-old boy has bilateral optic atrophy with diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus. 
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests Wolfram syndrome. It is due to WFS1 gene mutation. The presentation is usually between the ages of 5 and 21 years; diabetes mellitus is typically the 
first manifestation, followed by visual problems. It has a poor prognosis. Clinical features are: (DIDMOAD) • Diabetes insipidus • Diabetes mellitus • Optic atrophy • Deafness (sensorineural type) Option A: Kjer's optic neuropathy is an autosomal dominant condition. It presents with vision loss 
in early childhood and no significant systemic features. Option B: Behr syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. Clinical features include optic 
atrophy, pyramidal tract signs, ataxia, intellectual disability, urinary incontinence, and pes cavus Option D: Leber's congenital amaurosis is an autosomal recessive condition. It usually presents 
with significant vision loss in infancy and nystagmus. 527 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not a feature of amaurosis fugax ?
questions.explanation: Amaurosis fugax is a sudden and transient monocular blindness, which is reversible. It is a marker of advanced carotid artery atherosclerosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question: Question 17: Champagne cork disc is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Champagne cork disc is seen in chronic papilledema. The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork. Small drusen-like 
crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface. The most reliable sign to differentiate between papillitis and papilledema is pupillary reaction. 
Pupillary light reflex is normal in papilledema whereas it is sluggish in papillitis.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following defects is implicated in Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is a mutation of maternal 
mitochondrial DNA. Therefore the condition has a maternal inheritance. LHON causes bilateral, subacute painless loss of vision. The characteristic visual field defect is a 
centrocaecal scotoma. Pupillary light reflex is relatively preserved until the late stage of the 
disease. Optic neuritis and optic atrophy start in one eye and goes on to involve the other eye 
subsequently. It typically affects males between the ages of 15 and 35 years. The diagnosis of 
LHON should be considered in any patient with bilateral optic neuropathy, irrespective of age. Prognosis is poor, although some visual recovery may occur in a minority of cases even years 
later. Note: LHON plus refers to rare variants with additional manifestations such as neuromuscular 
dysfunction.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 19: A 34-year-old man developed a painless diminution of vision in his right eye 6 months ago 
but did not seek medical attention. Two weeks ago, he started to notice mild blurring in his 
left eye and has now come for evaluation. According to him, his elder brother and maternal 
uncle also had similar vision problems. Which fundus finding would point towards Leber’s 
hereditary optic neuropathy in this patient?

options.c: Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries

questions.explanation:
Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries would be suggestive of LHON. LHON is related to a mitochondrial DNA mutation. This results in impaired mitochondrial 
adenosine triphosphate production, which affects the highly energy-dependent optic nerve. In the acute phase, the optic disc is hyperemic and swollen with telangiectatic capillaries. 
However, the optic disc does not leak on fluorescein angiography. Later stages may show primary 
optic atrophy. 528 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 20: In order to diagnose a case as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which of the following 
features is not necessary?

options.b: Elevated opening pressure on lumbar puncture

questions.explanation:
Papilledema is not a mandatory criterion for the diagnosis of idiopathic intracranial hypertension 
(IIH). Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri) is a diagnosis of exclusion. 
Obstructive, compressive, and infiltrative CNS lesions must be excluded by neuroimaging studies. 
Papilledema, although present in 90% of the patients, is not necessary for diagnosis. Elevated CSF 
opening pressure on lumbar puncture is the hallmark of IIH. Risk factors of IIH include: • Female sex • Obesity • Nalidixic acid • Tetracycline • Vitamin A • Oral contraceptives • Use of or withdrawal from corticosteroids
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following is the most reliable sign to clinically differentiate between a case of 
papillitis and papilledema?
questions.explanation:
The most reliable sign to differentiate between papillitis and papilledema is pupillary reaction. Pupillary light reflex is normal in papilledema whereas it is sluggish in papillitis. Visual acuity and 
colour vision are also relatively more preserved in papilledema compared to papillitis. The other three disc signs seen on ophthalmoscopy are present in both papillitis and papilledema.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient evaluated for dizziness and visual disturbances was found to have down-beating 
nystagmus. A brain lesion was suspected and the patient was referred for an MRI. What is the 516 
Sold by @itachibot most likely site of the lesion?

options.b: Pineal region and the dorsal midbrain

questions.explanation:
Down-beat nystagmus is usually due to a lesion at the cervico-medullary junction (e.g. 
Arnold-Chiari malformation, syringobulbia) or as a manifestation of cerebellar degeneration. Other causes of down-beat nystagmus: • Drugs (phenytoin, lithium, barbiturates, carbamazepine) • Wernicke's encephalopathy • Demyelinating disorders Acquired nystagmus can be attributed to disturbances of the three mechanisms that normally 
ensure steady gaze—visual fixation, the vestibulo-ocular reflex, and the mechanism that makes it 
possible to hold the eyes at an eccentric eye position (e.g. far-right gaze). Other types of nystagmus: 529

questions.question:
Question 23: An RTA patient with severe head trauma is admitted to the surgical ICU for observation. On 
examination, nystagmus was noted. His CT scan reveals a transverse fracture of his left 
temporal bone. Which of the following statements is true regarding the nystagmus?

options.a: Slow phase is towards the left and fast phase towards the right
options.b: Slow phase is towards the right and fast phase towards the left
options.c: It is an up-beating type of nystagmus
options.d: It is a down-beating type of nystagmus

questions.explanation:
Fracture of the temporal bone causes vestibular injury resulting in a horizontal nystagmus with 
slow phase towards the affected side and fast phase towards the opposite side. Peripheral vestibular nystagmus occurs in lesions of the labyrinth or vestibular nerve. Normally, 
there is tonic input to the brainstem vestibular nuclei from the periphery. Loss of the tonic input 
from the left vestibular nerve leads to deviation of the eyes towards the left side, which is the slow 
phase of the nystagmus. The cortical correction brings the eyes back to the centre in the primary 
gaze which is the fast-phase directed towards the right side.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.explanation:
In internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) the lesion is at the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus on 
abduction on the contralateral side. When the gaze is initiated in the motor cortex, the horizontal 
gaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements. The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus which causes 
abduction of the ipsilateral eye. The second output is to the contralateral MLF which sends an 
impulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus causing contralateral adduction. These two 
outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side. 530 
Sold by @itachibot Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, 
however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia. The following image shows the pathway for horizontal eye movements as described above.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 25: You are evaluating an elderly patient in the stroke ICU, who was admitted three days back 
with a history of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and gait abnormalities. The visual 
examination showed conjugate horizontal left gaze palsy. He could maintain gaze near 
mid-position but could not cross the midline to the left side. His MRI is likely to show 
involvement of which of the following brain areas?
questions.explanation:
Horizontal gaze palsy can occur due to a lesion in parapontine reticular formation (PPRF). Horizontal gaze: • It involves 2 muscles- the ipsilateral lateral rectus and the contralateral medial rectus. • Center for this pathway is parapontine reticular formation (PPRF). • From here, they move to the ipsilateral 6th nerve nucleus. 531 
Sold by @itachibot • Next, they pass through the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral medial 
rectus subnucleus. Lesions affecting the abducens nuclei will also cause ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy, because of 
damage to motor neurons and internuclear neurons originating from the nuclei. Lesions involving 
the PPRF will lead to horizontal gaze palsy, as PPRF acts as a relay centre that connects the 
frontal eye fields in the cerebral cortex to the abducens nuclei. Conjugate horizontal gaze palsy 
can also be caused by lesion(s) involving both the abducens motor fibres and the MLFs preceding 
the abducens nucleus. Bilateral horizontal gaze palsy will be caused if lesion(s) involve both 
abducens nuclei or bilateral PPRF. Isolated damage to the MLFs will cause the classic INO where eye abduction is preserved, 
however, the ipsilateral eye will not be able to be adducted on conjugate horizontal gaze. Conjugate eye movements • Binocular movements in which the eyes move synchronously and symmetrically in the same 
direction. • Main types • Saccades: They are fast movements controlled by the contralateral frontal lobe. • Pursuits: They are slow following movements controlled by the ipsilateral occipital lobe. Image: The Horizontal gaze pathway Lesions in this pathway • Horizontal gaze palsy: Due to lesion in the PPRF of the same side • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO): Caused by lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus 
(MLF) • One and a half syndrome: Caused by lesions in both MLF and PPRF of the same side Vertical gaze palsy Center is located in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the dorsal midbrain (riMLF). 532 
Sold by @itachibot The important types of vertical gaze palsy are as follows: • Parinaud's syndrome: Upgaze palsy • Steel–Richardsons syndrome: Downgaze palsy
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 26: A patient has normal vertical saccades. On attempted left gaze as shown in the image below, 
the patient develops left jerk nystagmus. Where is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
The most likely location of the lesion according to the given clinical scenario and the image is 
the right medial longitudinal fasciculus. The image depicts an attempted left gaze and concludes that there is an adduction deficit in the 
right eye. This causes jerk nystagmus in the abducting left eye. This is most likely due to a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) ipsilateral to the 
side of the adduction deficit. Hence, this is a case of a right MLF lesion or Right Internuclear 
Ophthalmoplegia (INO).
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question:
Question 27: Ophthalmoplegic migraine clinically presents as  
.
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmoplegic migraine refers to headache associated with third, fourth, and sixth nerve palsy. Ophthalmoplegic migraine almost always involves the third nerve. Rare cases of sixth 
nerve involvement, and even rarer cases that involve the fourth nerve, have also been reported. Clinical criteria for the diagnosis of ophthalmoplegic migraine include: • A prior history of typical common or classic migraine headaches • Ophthalmoplegia that occurs during (or, rarely, just before) an established migraine attack • Exclusion of other reasonable causes by clinical and radiological studies 533 
Sold by @itachibot Tumors of Eye
